And, the character designs are excellent. Overall, I liked the show, though a little disappointed, I'd recommend for you to try it out.

Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis is easily the top-dog of 2014. And it's based off of a card game to boot. 
I'm very critical when it comes to anime, and I've never given out a 10/10 because nothing seemed worthy of it. Most animes I say barely go into 6 or 7 territory. This anime came insanely close to being my first 10/10. 
Every episode starts off with so much energy that it just makes you excited and keeps you watching. I was amazed the show could keep itself in check story wise due to the large scale world it presented. From start to finish, itfelt great. \n\n
The only thing I can really complain about, is the very final minutes. The ending felt satisfying enough and wrapped up almost 100% of everything it showed, but the flow of the show kind of lost itself. There was a lot of emotion in the final moments, but then it just drops suddenly when switching to another scene(you'll know what I mean if you watch it) and all the emotion is kind of lost. It felt pretty out of character for the show. There was no easing into it. It just kind of switched abruptly. If the show had an extra 5 or 10 minutes, I think it could have wrapped up into a perfect 10/10. \n\n
For my literal score, 9.4/10. Must-watch.

FAVARO!
alright - now thats out of the way, Shingeki no Bahamut is one of the amazing animes of 2014.
I find it, really impressive to use such a stereotypical plot of God, Demon and Humans -
and yet manage to captivate and provide us with 12 episodes of great entertainment.
The anime started with showing how overpowered Bahamut is - 
even with God, Demons and Humans working together to stop it was futile.
All they were able to do was seal Bahamut, which can be considered as a success if you may, but in reality was only delaying the inevitable.
Two thousand years of peace passed by, and we getto see our main characters Favaro, Kaiser and Amira (and Rita!) who will give us one hell of a ride from start to finish.

No slumps. No stalls. 

Just full awesomeness all throughout.


Animation: 9

I've seen better BUT... it is still amazing. 

I like the fact how something was ALWAYS moving.

If its not the characters then the background or props.


Characters: 10

Oh god - where to start, I just love how well made the characters are.

The main characters were really fun and entertaining especially Favaro.

but lets not forget, its all thanks to Kaiser that all of this was possible.


Amira, as the herione was intriguing especially how she's not the "moe-like" heroine - which is rather refreshing on top of the mysteries surrounding her.


and of course, Rita. The most helpful character in many ways.

Got to love her comments, just priceless.


While I didn't mention the other characters in detail, all i can say is -

I am amaze how every character had a significant role to play till they reached the final episode.


Music: 8

The Soundtracks especially the BGM are really nice and cool.


I have issues with the opening music.

While its suppose to "hype" everyone to the anime - 

I just find the amount of "shouting/screaming" going overboard.


Its just my concern which you can just disregard - otherwise OST and ED music is a 10.



Conclusion: 9


While I really love and appreciate how entertaining Shingeki no Bahamut is -

especially since this is one of the few animes of 2014 I would recommend...


For me, its missing that "masterpiece factor" that would warrant it a 10.

This became my favourite anime ever since I've watched it.
I have been watching anime for more than 10 years and it is one of the extremely rare animes that made me laugh so hard! It first was the fantasy setting with human, angels, demons that caught my eye. Then it was the amusement that made me carry on watching (as I didn't really care about the art style most people disliked) but then it brought in my favourite elements of adventure, friendship and romance.
After finishing the episodes, I could only say that this was a perfect story and an experience that everyone should try andenjoy.\n\n

Warning possible Spoilers
Going into Rage of Bahamut: Genesis I wasn't expecting much, especially considering this is based off a mobile card game so you couldn't really make much of a story out of it, yet to my surprise the more I watched it, the better it got.
Story (8/10)
The story concentrates on Favaro, a carefree bounty hunter, however his cosy life is interrupted when he meets a mysterious girl called Amira, but their meeting would cause the beginning of a major catastrophe.
Now the story at first had a LOTR feel to it, our main character finds a mysterious object or person and they need to getthem somewhere, this was enjoyable though seeing the different situations Favaro and Amira got caught up in which did produce a good couple of laughs.

Then once it reaches the midway point, we see Kaiser and Rita becoming more major characters and a big ass battle happens that really did feel like the battle at Helm's Deep, but it is at this point where the story does come to a slow crawl for me as we get more exposition on the situation and what it may lead to.

However the best was still to come, because the final episodes just blew me the fu*k away, some people might say the amount of stuff that happened made the anime feel rushed, but to me it was epic to watch even a little emotional at times and I felt really satisfied by the end of the show.


Characters (8/10)


What Rage of Bahamut definitely has is good characters, well mostly, there was the odd character that didn't feel right or just annoyed me a little, but the show managed to make some of these characters better by the end.

Favaro Leone is of course the best character, if not the best part of the whole show, because Favaro is one of those rare male protagonists who seems like a cool douchebag, which he technically is, but even when he does something stupid or makes a poor decision you just can't get mad at the guy and the amount of jokes he pulls out of his ass is just fantastic, there wasn't a single moment I hated the guy and his badass fighting skills just made him even more awesome. Although you do see his character change by the end in some way, he is a little more serious and does show his caring side towards his friends during the final battle, so he isn't always a cool douchebag, he actually has a heart somewhere.

Amira is a half Demon, half Angel who meets Favaro at the beginning of the series, I was originally thinking Amira was going to be one of those silent characters who wouldn't say a lot, but instead what I got was a glutenous, hyper, funny and very curious character. She was actually a bunch of fun when she was teamed up with Favaro who always mocked or joked around with each other. You also feel sorry for the girl at times too since all she wanted was to see her mother and their confrontation actually ends up being one of the more emotional parts of the show, Amira is that character who you can just have a fun time with, but also feel sad for them when something bad happens to them.

Kaiser Lidford who is a Knight turned bounty hunter, he was the weak link out of the main characters and seemed quite annoying at first especially whenever he would go on about Favaro screwing up his life, but slowly over time he actually becomes a decent character despite his stupidity and it was actually pretty cool seeing him and Favaro finally teaming up to defeat the bad guy.

Rita is a necromancer, despite not really saying all that much throughout the show, Rita ended up being an even better character than Kaiser for sure, because whenever Favaro or Kaiser did something stupid she would always end up whacking them or mocking them in a pretty savage way and this made her such an enjoyable character to have around. Not only that she knows a thing or two about making creepy potions that end up helping the others out during the final battle along with the fact she can bring anything dead into a zombie, which definitely helps if you're facing an army.


Art (8/10)


Despite a good abundance of CGI, it wasn't terrible CGI and I managed to stomach it, but aside from that it is amazing how Studio MAPPA managed to create such an interesting and detailed world from just a mobile card game and you have to admit that requires a lot of skill, which they pulled off very nicely.

I loved the clothing that the characters wore, it fitted their personalities and their occupation very well, plus I also liked the differences between the Angel and Demon races because for once they actually looked like they were proper Gods and would absolutely destroy you if you pissed them off.


Sound (9/10)


Even though the ed didn't do much for me, which isn't really a surprise, the op was friggin awesome. It's one of those op's that starts off alright, but the more you listen to it, the better it gets and the rock band style worked very well for depicting what the anime has in store for you.


Extras:


If there is one I can say about this show, is that it has brilliant comedy, true most of it is thanks to Favaro, but even Amira, Kaiser and especially Rita manage to come up with some truly funny moments, the chemistry between the characters worked really well and that is definitely one of the strongest parts this show had.

The action is also something that was pretty damn good, the battle at Anatae was really cool to see, despite feeling like an anime version of the battle at helms deep, but those final episodes were chock filled with great action moments and made me feel glad I watched this series.


Enjoyment (9/10)


Overall (8/10)


Overall this was a surprisingly good anime and has me looking forward to the Virgin Soul series that I will hopefully be watching very soon to close off my anime's for 2017.

Good story, lots of good plot twists and really cohesive within its universe most of the times, but with some cheap coincidences here and there and some unexplained stuff. The quality of the scenario and story makes me want more of it. But the ending lacked lots of explanations and had some inconsistencies.
Well paced, with only some problems in the last episodes where things were happening too fast. It kept me interested all the way to the end.
The characters are great and well developed. The chemistry between the main characters is amazing and really fun to watch. The author took the time needed to developthese characters and reveal their motivations and the result was really good. Some character arcs do not have an satisfying end.\n\n
It is visually very good, has a very fluid animation and the 3D sometimes bugged me, mainly in the end. In my opinion the quality of the animation is one of the best if not the best part of this anime.\n\n
The soundtrack is amazing, but it is not as memorable as it could be and sometimes the music does not fit the scene, mostly on some combat or epic scenes. But the voices and sounds are great, really immersed me in the scenes.

"Can these eyes lie?" 
"FAVAROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!"
^_^
This is roughly the summary of the most important sections of the anime. Ok, there is a bit of story in between, of this gurl Amira and some demons and angels and this super big ass bahamut guy that should not be freed ever again, but yea.

I could just write FAAAVAROOOOO and let you either wallow in confusion or watch the show to figure out what I am refering to, but even one such as I consider myself a bit more professional than that.
9/10
I read a bunch of reviews about this show before I watched it so I was expecting something nice. I still managed to be surprised.
How can that be if I got a good anime when I expected one? Shouldn't I have gotten exacly what I expected?
It's because this anime, this Shingeki No Bahamut, it does almost everything uniquely, and very well so. Mostly the characters, they're very welldesigned and it's not often in serious anime we get a character with an afro as an MC.\n\n
The bad rep of 12-episode-series, which usually don't have a real ending or are poorly animated and are only made to fill up screen time, have recieved a true hero. An ember that shines trough the darkness to light up the way. And all who shall follow shall be judged by this standard.\n\n
Bahamut will pull you in, it will introduce you to the characters masterfully, it will present it's story respectfully, and it will surprise you.\n
A show can be done well in only 12 episodes, this is proof. Shows that "need more episodes" are lackluster by comparison.

As you might already know, Rage Of Bahamut is actually an online Card Collection game brought to life thanks to Cygames, studio MAPPA, also Naoyuki Onda - serving as chief animation director and character designer, and more.
1) Story: The title says it all, but if you need more details...
Bahamut is a creature more powerful, in sense of magic ability, than any known human, angel,demon or even a God. Only by a miracle, the God Zeus and the Demon God united their power to seal Bahamut.  It has been 2000 years since Bahamuts' rage lasted upon the earth, and now, 2000 years later his sealis in peril. Humans, angels and  demons alike, fear Bahamuts' return. This immortal and terrifying being has endless passion for destruction and that is its only wish. Bahamut can only be resurrected by joining the 2 god keys kept across the cathedral of angels and the wretched demons' domain. Will they be able to protect the land if Bahamut is revived?


2) Art: Really beautiful art, magnificent scenery of fantasy nature. Majestically animated realms of the creatures known to us as angels and demons. I think that's about that, but there are also some battle scenes which look great in terms of animation, really cool.


3) Sound: You may have already heard the opening, or it's funny misheard lyrics that first got my attention to this masterpiece. By any means the music in the show is great, so are the voicing crews, generally good sound directing. At some points I had to turn down the volume because the screaming was performed very realistically, the neighbors would probably think somebody was really screaming in here. The ending theme was cute.

10/10 for the sound.


4) Characters: We meet the always fighting Hammer Head (Kaisar) and Bomber Head (Favaro) in the first episode. The past of these two and their arguments will be unraveled in the show. Later, we are introduced with the God Bacchus (a drunk), and also his duck. We also meet the beautiful, kind and sweet, yet hungry - Amira, Rita, who likes to call others kids, yet she looks like a kid herself. A glorious iron maiden, Jeanne d'Arc, blessed by the gods. The characters are astonishing. I forgot to mention the glorious angels. They are as bright and beautiful as the sun. We might as well say that the demons are a reflection of the moon. Light and darkness in balance.

I personally enjoyed the illuminating presence of the angels.


5) Enjoyment: Enjoyed every part of this amazing adventure. There was anticipation, mystery, funny moments, hungry moments, sad moments, happy moments, moments that make you go wow, and such. I was very curious to find out about the characters' pasts and what awaited them in the future.


6) Overall: Greatness. I am very pleased with Rage Of Bahamut. What I liked the most was Amira, she is awesome. I heard we are also getting a second season so I will be looking forward to that.

Hi. My name is Phil and I'm a huge fan of dark fantasy, especially when it's the kind of dark fantasy that mashes a lot of elements from different genres together and makes it somewhat plausible. So, yeah, I really like that kind of stuff. I loved Record of Lodoss War when it came out ten years ago, I dug the hell out of Berserk and Basilisk, I was genuinely entertained by last season's Hitsuge no Chaika and I was immensely disappointed by Blade and Soul that kinda sorta fit into that kind of anime as well (but, well, sucked like crazy from episode 4on out).


And, mark my words, we might have a new competitor for "Most Entertaining Dark Fantasy Anime in Recent Years", seeing as it has become kind of a trend in recent anime to go full dark fantasy on the viewers (a trend I support with all my heart and soul). MAPPA just goes all-out crazy this year with its series', first Summer Season's excellent Zankyou no Terror directed by oldschool-otaku favorite Shinichiro Watanabe (Cowboy Bebop, Macross Plus, Samurai Champloo), now this season's Garo (created by the same dude who gave us the decent cyberpunk-/girls with guns-B-action-OVA Iria) and this review's topic: Shingeki no Bahamut - Genesis, directed by oldschool-otaku favorite Keiichi Sato who took big parts in creating the City Hunter-OVAs, Tiger & Bunny and - of course - The Big O (which, if you haven't watched it yet, you should abso-freaking-lutely watch. Right. Now.).


The story is based on a collectible card game in which different factions are in kind of a cold war with one another after they successfully murdered a big-ass dragon called The Bahamut. Now, years later, a mysterious demon girl appears and takes one part of the key away that presumably might reawaken the dragon... or so we are led to believe right now. It's a classic "We have to go there to do that!"-plot that is told in an episodical fashion. Or, to put it simple: it'S 90s as fuck. A fact that I absolutely adore about this series. There's also a little love triangle thrown in there with said demon girl and two bounty hunters that follow her around, but it's not really in the foreground. So far, it's just a few characters caught up in a big ole mess involving humans, gods, demons, demon hunters, half-demons, pirates, zombies, zombie pirates, zombie pirate fish monsters that look like they came straight out of the black lagoon and giant enemy crabs. And a big-ass dragon. Yes, this series is completely out of its mind - in all the good ways.


So, the plot is very standard and kind of a clusterfuck - but trust me when I say that everything else about the series is top-notch stuff: you get three/four (depending on how you look at it) incredibly likeable main characters, each of them with their own little quirks and well-explained motivations behind their actions, each of them a badass in their own respective right and a cast of at least memorable supporting characters who might get their chances to shine individually in later episodes.


The visuals are beautiful, MAPPA clearly puts their A-game out in this series: crisp animation (especially in the action sequences the series has to offer) mixed with at least passable, sometimes even downright beautiful CGI-effects give me nice Blue Sub No. 6-flashbacks (and really make me hate Blade and Soul even more because that one had okay handdrawn animation and okay CGI, too - and Gonzo could've had a series this good as well!). The character designs are nicely done and are like a breeze of fresh air in the wasteland that is modern anime character-designs - no moe-schlock, no We-only-need-two-lips-animations-when-our-characters-talk-kinda deal, not too many still frames of stuff happening - there's always something nice to look at on the screen. I escpecially like the character's facial expressions. The constantly sceptical look an Amira's face whenever Leone tries to bs his way out of one of his many, many lies is priceless.


Now on to sound - did you google the opening yet? No? Google the opening. Listen to it. Now combine this with the orchestra- and choir-driven score of the series and the sadly kind of lackluster (but still okay) ending song and you get why I chose to give a 9 in this category, right? Need. Single. Now.


I gave the enjoyment category a 10, even though the series overall is a clear 9 for me. The 10 results not only from the fact that I haven't had this much fun with an anime series in years because of its action, its great comedy, its cool visuals and its extremely likable characters - but holy smokes, this series is also a freaking reference-fest! Not only to the card game itself, but also to a crapton of movies, video games, even a noteable hentai game-series! Just counting all these is a fun aspect of the show in and of itself, be it classic Errol Flynn-swashbuckler-movies, Evil Dead, italo westerns (name of one of the main characters *hint hint*), Dawn of the Dead, even freaking Macross - just seeing an anime paying hommage and also straight-up getting inspirations from these things is amazing and shows an ammount of effort and fanboydom I completely feel at home with.


So, if you like your dark fantasy action with a humorous edge and if you wanna feel like you're watching Lodoss War or Scrapped Princess (or any 90s-fantasy anime of your liking) all over again - give this one a watch, guys. Seriously, Bahamut needs a lot more love.

It's always a rare thing that an anime can pull me in the story with full force, probably because i'm a person with very specifics tastes and when something doesn't enthrall me at all, it won't defintely. 
Shingeki no Bahamut did much more than that: It sucked me first in to the story, which was very good and not so difficult to follow.   Its a fantasy story packed with action, mithological deities and emotions, primarly loyalty and friendship. The  screenplay is solid and never failed to bore me in any way, and the thing that amazed me most was the transitions betweenscenes which were perfectly smooth and placed at the right time! Obviously the story has its stale moments too, but in 12 episodes the screenwriters wrapped it up in a very good and personally satisfying manner.   It may not be the most oringial plot ever, but the way it is delivered is worth the effort to watch it!


Art and animation is gorgeous, perhaps one of the most beautiful art i've ever seen in an anime before. Face details and expressions fit every character shown, and they are depicted in a very good way.  The show sometimes relies heavily on CGI, but i didn't find it cringy like other animes i've watched in the past  maybe because it is based on an exisisting game and the director chose not to fucked it up too much.


Sound is outstanding, YES!  I adored the opening, which is heavy metal based, and the rest of the episodes which are mostly orchestrated in a movie-like way.  Cannot say more, but trust me it is frigging epic.


Regarding the characters, the three main protagonists alone are exceptional.  Side characters are well constructed too, and they mainly help shape the story until the very end.  The personalities of the main protagonists evolves in a natural and absolutely not cliched way,  and they deliver very well-written dialogues and motives for every action taken, be malicious or pleasent.


I binge watched the episodes in only 2 days maybe, and loved every piece of the show.  I think Shingeki no Bahamut shines in many many ways, foremost trying to be not pretentious and helping you realize that emotions are the core of everything.   At least, that's what i think.

SS Review – Rage of Bahamut: Genesis
(Short and Sour)
The story is about two bounty hunters who have a rivalry constantly fighting each other while one of them is trying to escort a demon to her mother. Also there is a dragon which everyone is scared of and a war between demons and angels (gods). So that’s pretty much the story in the shortest way I could possibly explain.
Animation is done by MAPPA back in 2008 which was the time when it was hit or miss for them but this is definitely a hit in the animation department. Sound design is good, OST fit the worldand scenes pretty well. Just too bad the opening is a bit over the top. The best part of this anime is the rivalry between the two main characters, one is a happy go lucky guy who does what he wants when he wants and will lie though his teeth to get that and the other is a knights son who is the living embodiment of a gentleman. So you can see that it’s no surprise these two characters do not get on.\n\n
Both of them get mixed up in said war against their will and that’s pretty much it. I don’t want to say much more, it’s definitely worth the watch if fantasy action is your thing. The happy go lucky main character is pretty funny at times. Yeah I would say its worth the watch, which is surprising as anime based off video games tend to sway to the worse side of things more than the good.\n\n
8/10\n

Shingeki no Bamut: Genesis is an inclusive anime from get the beginning or so it seemed. At the start I was expecting nothing more the a bland, compressed, with nothing new to offer. I’m glad to say I was proven but the anime upbringing and charms. Having no adaption manga, it would be though to be an original anime but in fact it takes after game for its source. However, you’ll be in for a pleasant surprise.
Story: 7
After an ongoing war between angels and demons our takes us few hundred/thousands of years into the future. Meet on of our three main protagonist Leone Favaro abounty living each day as if it were his last just barely escaping the capture Kaisar Lidfald, a knight as well as our second main protagonist. Anyhow, Leone is currently on quest in tracking down a bounty, with much charm and magic involve, Leone makes his capture seem like daily routine. Leone bounty is captured onto stone tablet with its face plastered like a card.


How does one celebrate such a success? Drinking at tavern until the peak of the moon night. Charming his ways with his money and good look Leone is able to catch the attention of two one who listen to his tales. Eventually, mentioning that he knows to get to ‘Helheim’ quickly. Overhearing this our last protagonist Amira hears this. When Leone makes his leave out of the tavern with his two lovely ladies, he’s stop in his tracks by none other than Amira. Their conversation is cut short due to another bounty presents itself, it’s the younger brother of the bounty Leone captured earlier. 


Underestimating his power Leone is outmatched and quickly defeated. Amira quickly deposes of him, but not as one would expect, it appears that she has the ability of a demon. In order to ensure to Amira route to Helheim, she kisses the unconscious Leone, bidding him to contract. When he wakens at Inn, bare naked he quickly catch of glimpse of his behind to see a devil tail growing out of it. Thus beginnings our adventure and journey to Helheim.


Art & Sound: 6 | 6


The sound is sound to astonishing only when it comes down to the more intense fight scenes or action scenes. I’m particular fond of Leone and Amiri tavern music between the two, were they find themselves dancing to. Animation wise is gorgeous, when the characters stand back to catch a glimpse of the landscape it’s as if you were staring at desktop background of your choosing. I find all the characters very unique looking especially Leone scar that stretches down his face, it shows the life of a bounty hunter. There is one downside though Kaisar, I can’t tell but the CGI models of him seem to stick out, other than that it’s implemented well at times. The opening really throws one off with the ‘Hard Rock’ or ‘Punk Rock’ music doesn’t seem fit tone, although it grows on you over time. The ED isn’t too much special even more plain that the OP.


Characters: 7


Leone Favaro – Charming and appealing is one the many skills and assest a bounty hunter has in order to get what he wants. When it comes Leone it’s obvious he puts himself over others being deceitful to Amira in other to snatch a kiss from her. Even mention to the Royal Knights that she’s a demon all for some ransom money. He’s a guy with intentions for himself always come first but has a change of heart later on.


Kaisar Lidfard – Coming from a wealthy and honorable family. However, he’s forced to make a living a bounty hunter, something he’s not to found off and disgraceful to his family name and honor in the eyes of others. Kaisar is on the hunt of Leone wanting revenge on the man. A man with a code and honor to defend.


Amira – She’s the quite one that doesn’t like to converse much with others, though things change when she meets Leone, becoming more outspoken and charming. Receiving a major wardrobe change, she doesn’t know much of the current era she’s living in. It’s through Leone that she learns what stars are and much. No question she’s a demon but one that’s on the look for her mother that the sole purpose of her journey to Helheim.


Enjoyment: 5

Coming into this anime I didn't know what to expect- honestly I figured I probably shouldn't expect a whole heck of a lot- but I was pleasantly surprised by the many things RoBG does right. Not a perfect show by any means, RoBG does enough things right to make it a ride worth taking that I think most anime watchers will enjoy.
Art-
This is a relatively modern anime and it is very nice visually. It's crisply and vibrantly animated, animations are fluid throughout (which is a huge plus for an anime loaded with fast moving action scenes) and the aesthetic design choices are very fitting forthe story this anime wants to tell. At no point was my jaw on the floor at the sheer beauty of any given scene, but I was definitely impressed and found it nice to look at throughout.


Sound-


Brina Palencia, Tia Ballard, Christopher Sabat and other huge names in the voice acting world lend their efforts to the Dub (which is what I watched) and it's really hard to go wrong with that kind of talent in your corner. The voice acting here is top notch and gets a perfect score or damn close to it as far as I'm concerned. The voice acting for this particular anime probably wasn't easy either as so many of the characters are super quirky and this anime brilliantly switches from something humorous to something serious in a blink.


The music throughout was fine and that's about it. I liked the ending credits song for sure, though I didn't care for the intro song. None of the background tracks particularly stood out to me, for better or for worse. It just felt very average. There isn't any track I'll still remember three months after watching this anime or would add to my personal playlist.


Sound effects were crisp and believable.


Character/Story-


This anime is extremely character/story driven and for such a short anime (only 12 episodes) there are a lot of important characters who genuinely matter as far as the bigger picture plot is concerned. I feel they did as good a job as anyone could realistically do in developing these characters and making me care about them with such a low episode count, but ultimately there is a limit to how far that can go without more time. All four of the main leads have very different quirks and personalities and they're all quite likable in their own ways.


As an avid competitive Shadowverse player it was really weird to me, and not in a good way, to see Shadowverse characters included in this anime. I understand why they're there (Cygames, the company that makes Shadowverse, is heavily tied into this anime as well) but it felt more weird and awkward than it did cool. It was hard for me to take those characters seriously or care about them as much. This is one design decision I didn't care for.


The story here is pretty good and it keeps you guessing all the way til the end, but the ending itself was really disappointing. It was very predictable and cookie cutter and it felt rushed.


Enjoyment-


With the fast pace and high volume of action in this anime combined with likable, quirky leads this anime gets high marks for enjoyment/entertainment value. As stated previously, the ending wasn't satisfactory to me and felt rushed and I think this anime would have been better with an episode count closer to 16, but it was a nice ride for what it was.


Overall-


Rage of Bahamut Genesis does a lot of things right- It's a proper adventure that is fast paced and has action scenes in every episode, the four lead characters are all very quirky and likable in their own way and the voice acting is rock solid. If not for being a few episodes too short and having an extremely safe, cliche, rushed, predictable ending this would be a great show, but as it stands it is merely very good.


+Pretty

+Great voice acting

+Original story + plot twists

+Quirky, likable leads who didn't remind me of leads from any other anime


-Disappointing ending

-Too few episodes

-Awkward inclusion of Shadowverse characters


OBJECTIVE RATING- 8

PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- 8

Ah, Shingeki no Bahamut, a show which I nearly dropped halfway through. However, boy am I glad that I didn't drop it. 
Story - 6
The story is "fair". It started off as a pretty average story, everything was predictable and even boring to an extent, however the ending did surprise me quite a lot. Though there were some unexplained things there. Anyhow, there isn't much character development nor are there many deep themes which delve into the depth of mankind and nature, however, I can see how some people may enjoy this show. Let's just say that I am NOT one of those people.
Art -8


The art is probably my favourite aspect of the story, though I didn't really like the style. Everything else was pretty nice, animation was ok, proportions were great. I barely saw any misdrawn faces and the action scenes can be quite intense. The environment however, was beautiful, and it was probably my favourite aspect of the artwork of this show.


Sound - 7


The sound was.... average. However, I can say that the opening theme saved the show.


Character - 6


I found the characters to be uninteresting and unrealistic (apart from the zombie girl). However, I really enjoyed the way that they interacted with each other. Not much development happened but I might just miss them now.


Enjoyment - 4


Enjoyment, the most important part of watching anything. You should enjoy it before you critically review it. Sadly, I didn't enjoy the show and half of it just felt like I was sitting through class. Actually, I would have rather studied for maths than watched some parts of the show.


Overall - 6


Yeah, it wasn't too good. But it is definitely worth a watch.

I'll keep this review short and concise.
I recently finished Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis and this is what I thought about it.
Story (7): 
I feel like the story could've been much more than it was. It certainly had potential to take many exciting paths, but opted for safer less-than-exciting routes.
Art (8): 
I personally liked the art. It had enough detail to look rich and the colors were fresh. The animation was very good too, and didn't disappoint in the action scenes.
Sound (6):
This is the least interesting part of this anime for me. Soundtrack was nothing special, and sometimes it even annoyed me a bit. 
Character (8):
Thecharacters are really interesting and don't follow the annoying/overused tropes. There's also a good dynamic between them that'll entertain. \n
Enjoyment (7): I enjoyed the anime quite a bit. It was far from a masterpiece, but had a lot of good moments.\n
Overall (7.5): Action anime lovers who want to see something different, unique and interesting should check Shingeki no Bahamut. While it may not be an excellent series, it has a lot of enjoyable moments that'll keep watchers interested until the very end.

When I first saw the preview for the season, hearing that there was going to be an anime based on a smart phone game, I dismissed it as a cash grab, seeing as most games on smart phones are either scams or cash grabs. However, after the first episode there was a fair amount of hype for the show, so I decided to join the crowd and give it a watch. To my surprise, Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis was a pleasant experience. But there is one aspect of the show that holds it back; time.
The first episode does well to draw the audience in tothe world of Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis. The goal of the show is made apparent within the first few scenes; Bahamut, a dangerous dragon-like monster may come back one day to destroy the world. The main characters are then introduced in a well choreographed battle across a medieval town. The visuals and the music of the battle give a strong sense of adventure and fun and primes the audience for what's ahead. Quickly after the introduction of Amira, the story is set as the characters embark on their journey across this interesting world.


Sadly though, the journey doesn't last long. Within six episodes the main characters are back at the beginning and the show starts building up to its climax. This, perhaps, stems from the fact that Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis was only given 12 episodes to tell its full story. The beginning of the show gives a feeling similar to Lord of the Rings or Avatar the Last Airbender; the characters are going to explore the world, learning along the way before leading to the climax where everything comes together. However, the show only gives a teaser of its world. This leads to a fairly mediocre conclusion where scenes that should be emotional instead feel forced and lack any weight. The time constraint issues affect the pacing too. Battles go faster than they should, time within the show moves quickly and there are very few scenes that actually allow time for the audience to absorb the gravity of what's going on. This also negatively affects the character and plot development, speeding through scenes to get to the next plot point. 


Nevertheless, there are plenty of memorable moments along the way to keep the audience entertained. The characters are interesting and their interactions are genuinely delightful to watch. The action is done well enough together with the soundtrack. The comedy mostly hits the mark and doesn't harm the tone of the show. The story doesn't leave any questions unanswered either.


In the end, Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis is an anime that I wish had more time given to it. I wanted to know more about the world. I wanted to see the characters go through many different towns and scheme their way through various situations. I wanted more time to grow attached to the characters and understand the  gravity of the impending release of Bahamut. Instead, what the anime ended up being was a teaser for what could have been. Still, if people want to give this show a go I would recommend watching it. But, perhaps put other better shows as a higher priority.

Coming right from Cygames is the finally released "Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis" or as it is known in the card game rpg world, "Rage of Bahamut."
To give a little background info, "Rage of Bahamut" is a card game that is produced by Cygames that this anime series is based off. I will dive further into the anime being based off the card game, but the rpg game isn't too bad. Check it out if you have the time!
Anyways, a story of a young man helping a girl get to someplace and fight off enemies on the way there. That's the series in a nutshell andI'd say it sounds pretty generic or general for anime now, but here are my thoughts on it. 


Story: 8/10


The storyline is quite simple, which allows for more wiggle room for action and humour and lots of other add-ons to make it interesting. Like I said, it's an adventure of getting someone from one place to another because of some wish the person wants. Pretty normal, but one things SnB really excels at is progress. It does not lag behind for the sake of superfluous action or forced comedy and it progresses very well.


Art: 7/10


Hmm. From a card game, I would expect a lot for art and I do have to say that from the first 2 episodes I was not very impressed by the artwork. However, it does progressively get better as they reveal more characters. The human character designs are quite normal and do not interest me much, but SnB does a fine job in detailing the demons and angels' designs. Very nice touch.


Sound: 9/10


SnB does an excellent job in sound! The opening "Existence" is very metal and rock which just resonates how this anime is an action/adventure! What really draws me in is the OSTs in battle. Now this is one of the epitomes of SnB. Very nice OSTs that compliment the battle scenes and action scenes.


Character: 8/10


Original is not a word I would use, yet they are unique! Their designs are okay in terms of unoriginality, but their traits are what enhances them the most! Very dynamic characters and very big cast full of interesting creatures! Yes, there are angels, dragons, demons, dragoons, zombies, and many others that may sound staple, but there are qualities that make them undeniably great.


Enjoyment: 9/10


The first 2 episodes made me question my interest, but after the 4/5th, I was happy to say that i liked it and I will continue watching it. Every episode has its own uniqueness to it, so it does not just copy one episode or just recap everything.


Parallel to Game


This is where I want to point out my opinion. RoB and SnB is in the medieval times of 3 realms, humans, gods, and demons! However, I was not expecting a somewhat new cast and even a different "mechanism." I was hoping for some mechanisms (like Holy Wars/Evolution/Castle Crushers) to be incorporated formally. Nevertheless, the anime was not disappointing and is still well done!


Overall: Very nice anime with a sluggish start. The episodes get better and the most recent episode (episode 7) was just amazing and I would say the apex of the last 7 episodes. I recommend this to people who play Rage of Bahamut (free to play in the App Store!) or people who enjoy watching action/adventure/thrillers as well as rpg-players since the setting is really rpg-like! 8/10 in total! Give SnB some more love guys! :D

If you're like me and you've watched enough TV/read enough books/played enough games, you'll be able to figure out mostly where the main story is headed within the first few episodes, but frankly that doesn't even matter, because the visuals getting there BLEW. ME. AWAY. It wasn't so much about the story itself (although there were many parts I didn't see coming and I really did enjoy the story as a whole!) but how our heroes got to the end. 
This anime is stunning to watch. The main characters are fantastic, well-rounded and thoroughly engaging. There are dragons, demons, gods, angels and that's only someof it, I don't want to spoil the rest for anyone, but there really is more. The best part is it does't feel like a horrible mish-mash of differing fantasy genres (and a hint of sci-fi too), instead it all blends together seamlessly in a fantastical world I have always wanted to see. 


There is the odd point that just didn't make 100% sense (such is the way with anime and the fantasy genre in general), and one or two points which could have been lingered over just a bit longer (maybe 13 episodes instead of 12?), but those are truly minuscule setbacks which take away none of the enjoyment of this anime. 


It's become an instant favourite of mine and there was always at least one point in each episode where I literally went 'woah' either at the pretty or at the cleverness of some of the storyline. I loved every second.


This is fantasy done right.

Imagine having just a card game as source material for an action, adventure, fantasy anime you have to make. MAPPA studios took that challenge and turned a battle card game with no more source material than some conceptual artwork and with as much plot as a cardboard game can have, into a really good anime that even had potential for a masterpiece. I am talking about the 2014 anime, Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis, also known as Rage of Bahamut and here is the review to it. Enjoy!
PLOT AND STORY LINE
Shingeki no Bahamut is set in an alternative version of medieval France in a world whereevery possible fantasy creature exists. The story sets off with an old tale about the ancient dragon Bahamut that brought about destruction to the land of Mistarcia two thousand years ago. Only by working together, the gods and demons were able to save the world, sealing the dragon away and creating a key to keep him imprisoned forever. They key was split into two halves, one being kept by each deity, but the long lasting peace would again be threatened after one of the halves gets stolen. In a world that is about to face new danger we meet our two protagonists-the bounty hunters Favaro and Kaisar who, in terms of personality, couldn't be more different. The bounty haunting life that they knew would soon be over after Favaro accidently meets a mysterious woman that goes by the name Amira. 

Now, the story itself sounds promising and is really intriguing but for some reason I found it rather boring in the beginning. It is in the second half where the anime finally drew my full attention to the story. The second half puts all the pieces together and you finally understand what is going on. Moreover, new plot twists and surprises are just the beginning of the excitement as the anime slowly moves towards its huge finale. Amazing battles, emotional background stories and character side stories are just some of the elements that turned Shingeki no Bahamut into a really good anime in the end. And when it comes to the first half, I would have probably dropped the anime if it weren't for that one story element-the relationship between Favaro and Kaiser.

Even though the story does have its ups and downs, it is the two protagonists that actually keep your attention, especially in the beginning. The story element of two characters that hate each other, yet are obliged to work together, never gets old and in case of Shigeki no Bahamut it definitely contributes to its entertainment factor. The way their contradictory personalities interact keeps the anime amusing and always open for new surprises. What's more, an interesting background story about Favaro and Kaiser is woven into the main story as it reveals the true reason for their everlasting fight and hatred.

In short, you might find the story of Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis hard to follow in the beginning, but I promise you an entertaining and slightly emotional story full of action and amazing fights later on. 


CHARACTERS

If there is one thing that Shingeki no Bahamut did without a single flaw, then it is the characters. The character design is so remarkable and unique, and even though I am not a huge fan of the style I have to praise MAPPA for their outstanding work. But the thing that was even better than that was the fact that each character actually had a distinctive personality. 

The personalities of the main characters are of course the most noticeable ones, especially when it comes to Favaro and Kaiser. Favaro is a carefree bounty hunter that finds the purpose in life in three things alone: money, women and wine. Lies and scams are part of his everyday life whereas his life-moto would be his father's quote: „Which way is the wind blowing? To tomorrow! “. Kaiser, on the other hand, is a very serious and mature young man that also lives the life of a bounty hunter. Noble by birth, Kaiser was once a knight and so he still behaves, all according to the codex of knighthood. Amira, the leading female is a naive, sweet and rather childish young girl that is not truly aware of her powers. She was definitely one of my favorites form the show and it was her character design on the anime cover that drew my attention to Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis in first place.


ANIMATION AND STYLE

Just as I said before, one of the greatest things about the anime is definitely its style. Both the setting and character design are amazing and more importantly distinctive among other anime. One thing I did have a problem with was the animation. All in all, it was not bad, but it lacked in contrast. The heaven scenes were too bright, the demon scenes were to dark and in some parts you just couldn't clearly see what was going on. The quality of the animation was mediocre in my opinion, but I have to say that it was still enjoyable to watch. 


CONCLUSION

Even though Shingeki no Bahamut: Genesis is solely based on a battle card game, the anime had potential to turn into a masterpiece. Unfortunately, it didn't come to that. The lack of excitement in the beginning and the flaws in the animation made the anime less enjoyable but it is nevertheless a really good anime that is worth your time. What saves the anime is definitely its intriguing historical-fantasy setting and the quality of the characters. Simply put, Shingeki no Bahamut might not be a masterpiece but it still deserves to be part of the completed section on your anime list.

Video Script:
Rage of Bahamut: Genesis (6/10): To learn about my rating system check the description below. Now it is time to ooze into this spoilery review. 
Rage of Bahamut Genesis is fun, and for an anime adaptation of a videogame it is pretty darn special. There are moments where the animation is truly mind blowing, the first episode being a fantastic over the top introduction to the style and the characters. Where Bahamut struggles is a feeling of consistency, the characters start out doing odd jobs going after bounties, then they are havinga dramatic sea battle, then they are dealing with demons is a floating Cthulhu fortress, then they are bumming around a castle oh wait now they are engaged in defending the castle from a demonic onslaught, now they are in an alternate dimension chatting up a dragon, and now there is a demonic insurrection. A sizable issue is the a main villain that feels underwhelming as their motives are unknown and their character has been playing a very reserved role up until now but suddenly is crazy? The world doesn't feel very realized as it pulls from way to many areas at once, for example they keep referencing Satan but honestly he played little to no role in the show. The magic system is also a problem as the show tries to place dramatic weight on magical actions being taken, but you never know how powerful any given beam of magic light is supposed to be as it all starts to blend together after awhile. It makes up for its scattered world and narrative by having a fun cast of zany characters that, for the most part, remain consistent. If you are willing to overlook some crazy plot and magic conveniences than Rage of Bahamut Genesis can be an entertaining adventure to follow.   \n

This is a rare high quality high budget anime, which reminded me of masterpiece titles like Samurai Champloo or Cowboy Bebop. Over the course of the story, it manages to unfold a story that is bigger than heroes involved, and displays complex and convoluted world with a large number of characters and beings inspired by or based on real world legends and even occasional historical figure. It is a very solid show that is worth watching... but somehow it doesn't reach that quality bar where you could call it a masterpiece, even though all the elements seems to be here. 
Detailed breakdown below:
Story: 8/10
Aside froma very small number of highly cliched stereotypical story turns, it is fairly solid and interesting to watch. The show managed to properly keep the events going, unfolding into something bigger and bigger, it also managed to paint the main threat in the show in proper manner - where you can't just dismiss it as a plot device and feel a bit f respect to it. The story has that slight issue where it is occasionally quite obvious that some events happen to impress the viewer (i.e. you see few events as plot devices), but that doesn't happen very often. The story is very solid.


Art: 7/10:

High quality art with nice character designs. There are different kind of fantastic creatures, some of which are huge, and there are bunch of very nice looking/beautiful  characters of each gender. The issue with art is that the anime uses a lot of CG (it couldn't happen without it, to be honest), and CG is noticeable. It isn't UGLY kind of CG (like those horrible monsters in Ga Rei Zero, for example), but there's a noticeable contrast between hand-drawn frames and CG-rendered backgrounds and creatures, which is very obvious.


Sound: 7/10:

Sound is good, with many great musical themes that were supposed to feel epic. The probelm is that while they were interesting to listen to, I felt like the music coudl use more punch in it, especially those tracks with choir that is supposed to be awe-inspiring. I felt that music, despite being good, fell short in many battles. Intro soundtrack was great, though.


Character: 5/10:

The story mostly revolves around the world and the thread, and not about characters, meaning they don't really have much chance to fully display their characters/personalities. Characters coudl definitely use more depth, because at times they almost look like plot devices that are supposed to do this or that thing, rather than people. Still, main heroine was quite interesting to watch....


Enjoyment: 8/10:

I liked it. I liked the way events kept unfolding, and how this anime kept displaying different aspects of the world, shifting perspectives and in the end giving a big picture of the strange realm where the events happen. It doesn't reach its full potential, but it was better than I expected.


Overall: 8/10:

Highly recommended to check it out. While it may not qualify for a "masterpiece" level material, this kind of solid work is uncommon.

May I just say well done.  I actually watched this when it was released, but man the Subbed really killed it for me.  Well let me be frank and say 7 out of 10 which is why I am watched it again.  This time I watched it dubbed and may I just say it was so good it could make me cry.   I can say it is worth watching and watching dubbed at least in English.  No idea who they got to voice him but the sames joke told in subbed were a "ow that is cute/quaint" but indubbed with his tone is just makes it for me.  That is my rant, just watched dubbed even if your a subbed master they did a way better job with the tone and projection in the dubbed.

SNBG is proof that one little white lie could cost you a life. This is the best adaptation I've seen from a game series, cause most turn out poorly unfortunately. I personally do not like the adventure genre but would still definitely recommend it it's shining points surpass its little flaws.
⠀⠀ The first few minutes into the series is a little overwhelming with it just throwing you in to what SNBG is, but it definitely makes up for it explaining everything by the end. Demons and Angels are the gods of this world. While our protagonists are mostly human, the main spotlight is on thesetwo different groups during the action sequences. The animation really shines here from Mappa showing how overpowered these Angles and Demons are. \n
⠀⠀ ⠀⠀The soundtrack was nice definitely adding a lot to the overall feel during action sequences. But I found myself forgetting most of it, as the action on screen was overpowering it sorry Ike Yoshihiro.  I need a stronger chorus to support the action. ⠀⠀⠀\n
⠀⠀I generally like the plot of SNBG and don't really have any complaints about it. But I definitely am disappointed with the antagonists, they didn't explain really any of their motives. There was a lot of villains but where's their insides? Cerberus was probably the most unloved character, she started as a piece of cardboard and that's how she ended. Unfortunately that's how most of the supporting characters are treated throughout. The main antagonist just wanted world domination for the sake of world domination. Blah blah I rest my case.\n
⠀⠀Even with the poor supporting characters I still recommend this series, It's a thrill ride of a good adventure series done right.

Personal Rate: 6
Average Rate based on the different criteria: 6.4 rounded down to 6
I came to watch this anime without knowing it was an adaptation from a card game. Overall, let's just say that it feels incredibly rushed and overall I just couldn't get as invested as I wish I had. The problem probably stems from the wide array of characters depicted... If the series had mostly focused on Favaro and Kaisar, I guess it would have made for a fairly enjoyable ride... instead I just got bored senseless.
Story: 5
Art: 9
Sound:  6
Character: 6
Enjoyment: 6
Overall: 6
Story: 5
Obviously given the short length, the story is prettystraightforward... and it would not have been a problem if it had been character driven but we're shown a whole bunch of things which I guess will appeal to original fans of the game but which only adds to a feeling of confusion overall. Had the story not bothered with useless detours and focused more on the mains, it would have been a pleasant ride in spite of the empty plot.


Art: 9


Top notch. Totally gorgeous. In fact, I started this anime for the art I stumbled upon surfing on the web. Apart from Cerberus which character design seems to be straight out of a bad bdsm hentai, it is a feast for the eyes. Favaro in particular has one of the most ridiculous haircut I ever saw in an anime and still manages to rock it like it's the coolest thing ever. I mean, gosh, he looks cool. The same can be said about the other characters (except Rita but again she's got the body of a child) but Favaro is to me certainly one of the most gorgeous character design I had the chance to see. The action scenes are well executed as well but minus 1 point for the use of 3D which doesn't always looks as integrated as it should with the 2D elements.


Sound: 6


It's okay but totally forgettable. I doubt I can remember any theme song I heard watching it. In fact, it is so bland, It sounds like any average fantasy music ever... Only exception to the rule is the hard metal opening which made my ears bleed - not my thing at all. I heard it twice because man does the opening looks cool and fit well with the music, but then I decided I'd spare my sensitive ears and skip it altogether. 

The ending, is your classic ballad, forgettable but at least you won't become deaf listening to it.


Character: 6


Too many. Again as said above, it's probably a tribute to fans of the game but if you never played it, you'll have trouble getting attached to any of them. Only characters we spend more time on are Kaisar and Favaro but it still is not enough. Both are drawn being the typical rival/friend/antagonist but the depth of their relationship though hinted at is not highlighted enough for us to care. Then there's this whole bunch of characters whether demons, humans or angels thrown in the mix which motivations apart from preventing bahamut's wake and staying alive for some, is obscure. The worst is when you get to the end of the series and you get these twists but you're not given a chance to know why the hell this character did that and if he/she did, err, who are they really?

This had to do more with the length... A bit more time spent with each of them would have been great at least to understand their motivations.

Unfortunately with 12 episodes, they can only be classified into two groups: "Save the world" or "Rule the world".  No gray area there.


Enjoyment: 6


Favoro+ Kaisar + Amira: YAY

Rest: Bleh


The action scenes especially towards the end are so long that I ultimately got bored. I didn't even want to bother.


Overall: 6


Shingeki no Bahamut Genesis is an ok anime. But great animation can't save empty characters and confusing plot. It lacks soul. This being said, if you've got  time to waste, it's not a  bad deal. If you're busy with life and don't want to start an addicting anime, this one is pretty cool. It's got action, likable mains and the scenario is so predictable, you won't be hung on the cliffhangers... This being said, I think I'll give the second season a chance since it's got twice the amount of episodes. I'm hoping the increasing length will work in their favor.

SMALL SPOILERS BELOW!!!
First of all I would like to say that I had heard very little about this series when it first came out besides knowing it is based off a mobile card game. My initial thoughts were is it just another one of those mobile based card games that I could easily brush off to the side without a second though which I did. 
However as one of my good friends had completed the show he suggested I check it out and give it a go. So why not, going into it I was really surprised at how great it turned out as Iwas launched right into an adventure with our protagonists and seeing their journey from one location to the next. The action is spectacular and the comedy here and there is always fun to watch. 


Story: 9/10


In the past the dragon (Bahamut) came close to destroying the whole world. However with the humans, gods and demons working together they were able to seal the beast and split the key into two parts so that they would never be connected again to prevent Bahamut from reviving once more. Many years later a girl named Amira stole one of the keys and from here on is where the adventure begins. This may sound generic, but the execution of how it is portrayed is what I found to be enjoyable.


Sometimes it felt like I was watching a movie due to how fast the pacing went which was actually a good thing in some parts.  


Art: 9/10


I found the art to be done very well and beautifully. The animation on certain monsters was done quite well, even when they were 3DCGI I found them to be menacing and the detail on them is very nice. The scenery and background I just loved as it is really reminiscent of a fantasy type anime. I was amazed at how good the animation was especially when this was based off a card game. 


Sound: 9/10


I found the opening Song "EXiSTENCE" by SiM a fantastic way to get you pumped and excited heading into each episode. The scenes where there was a massive battle occurring felt like something big was going to happen which the music complimented it very well. 


Character: 9/10


I am going to mention the four main characters/protagonists of the series.  


Favaro is a bounty hunter that goes around claiming bounties which he spends on alcohol, food and women. He is often silly and the face he makes when he is trying to be serious is quite funny. In terms of skill and combat he is a competent fighter who is good at using a sword and always has a trick up his sleeve when in a tight situation. 


Amira’s beauty, lovely pink hair and personality is what I like about her character. She is simple-minded and doesn’t seem to know much about the world around her. She loves to eat and is usually the only thing she thinks about. Her demon form when I first saw it is freaking awesome and the way she fights is glorious to see. She is someone you don’t want to mess with.


Kaiser was once a noble knight. However an incident involving his father led them to losing their titles and since then has become a bounty hunter like Favaro. 


Rita the zombie girl I would say is my favorite out of the four. She is a necromancer who has the ability to control the dead. However she is bitten and later on becomes a zombie, but stills has the ability to think for herself. I love how she is always calm around the other three and likes to break up situations, especially when Favaro and Kaiser get into fights. Her powers are quite handy and can definitely turn the tables against an opponent. With one bite she is able to take full control of anything living or dead. You would think when watching her interact with the others she doesn’t seem to really care about them, but in actual fact she is always looking out for them and is always keeping an eye on her surroundings. I am also a big fan of Sawashiro, Miyuki who voices here so that was an added bonus. 


Enjoyment: 9/10


I thoroughly enjoyed this show a lot more than I should have. The action was fantastic especially the massive battles that occurred every so often. I loved the characters. Each of them had a unique charm about them which I found enjoyable to watch while getting to know them.  


Overall: 9/10


A great fantasy anime with plenty of action and adventure in only 12 episodes that I would recommend to anyone. A straight forward story, but the way it was done kept me wanting more. You got humans, demons and gods involved, what more could you ask for.

The story is some good ol' fun adventure... At least at first sight, as it is SIGNIFICANTLY deeper than that... 9/10 but it gets 10/10 from the extra points that I wanted to give the characters.
Art and Sound do not even need commentary. 10/10
The characters... This is probably what made the anime REALLY good, not just good. It deservesd FAR more than 10/10!
Enjoyment, 10/10
Overall, it is the 2nd best or best anime I have ever watched. (Not that I watch a lot of anime, but I have a very high threshold when it comes to even deciding to PEEK AT an anime, so that iswhy I only watched 3 or 4 anime so far.)
